content: The Std.Tactic folder is a holdover from mathlib were most metaprogramming utilities are grouped into a generalization notion of tactics. While this is justified in the mathematical context, it is much more confusing for the CS context of the stdlib (at least in my view). As such, I think it would be a good idea to rename this folder to something more general (like Meta, Lang, or Elab) and/or split the folder into many (e.g., Tactic, Command, DSL, etc.) as stdlib is likely to have an even larger variety of metaprogramming utilities than mathlib.
Are there examples of languages with metaprogramming bundled in their standard libraries?
I am mainly asking if there is anything comparable to our situation or a general expectation a programmer might have when searching for metaprogramming capabilities in the standard library.
Scala puts some definitions in scala.compiletime, but Lean.Meta sounds good to me
@James Gallicchio I imagine it would be Std.Meta (or whatever name e decide on), no?
Tactic, DSL, Command sounds good to me, mathlib already has Tactic and Util containing language extensions, which while I initially found confusing definitely makes sense
